title: Trigonometry Foundations
description: Comprehensive development of trigonometry: radian measure, the unit circle, all six trigonometric functions (definitions, graphs, properties), fundamental identities (Pythagorean, reciprocal, quotient, cofunction, even-odd), and solving trigonometric equations. This is the largest unit and builds the foundation for all subsequent trig work.
goals: Convert between degrees and radians; compute arc length, sector area, and angular speed.
Evaluate all six trig functions at standard unit circle angles (multiples of π/6, π/4, π/3) and determine signs by quadrant.
Graph sine, cosine, tangent, cotangent, secant, and cosecant including amplitude, period, phase shift, and vertical shift using y = A·sin(B(x - C)) + D.
Apply fundamental identities (Pythagorean, reciprocal, quotient, cofunction, even-odd) to simplify and verify trig expressions.
Solve trigonometric equations on specified intervals and find general solutions using reference angles and periodicity.
Model periodic real-world phenomena (Ferris wheels, tides, temperatures, sound waves) using sinusoidal functions.
instructionalStrategy: Gradual release: concept-intro → I Do → concept-check → We Do → check-in → You Do → mastery-check
AI uses scaffold array as scope and worked-example bank; AI makes all instructional decisions
Unit circle mastery is non-negotiable — daily practice embedded
Graphing connects algebraic parameters to visual features systematically

scaffold.title: Radian Measure, Arc Length & Sector Area
scaffold.content: The radian is the standard unit of angle measurement in mathematics. One radian is the angle subtended by an arc equal in length to the radius. There are 2π radians in a full revolution.
keyPoints: Conversion: degrees × (π/180) = radians; radians × (180/π) = degrees
Arc length: s = rθ (θ in radians)
Sector area: A = (1/2)r²θ (θ in radians)
Angular speed: ω = θ/t (rad/time); linear speed: v = rω = s/t
Coterminal angles: θ ± 2πn (or θ ± 360°n)

examples.problem: Convert: (a) 225° to radians, (b) 7π/5 to degrees. (c) Find two coterminal angles for -π/3.
A circle has radius 10 cm. Find the arc length and sector area for a central angle of 2π/3.
A wheel of radius 2 feet rotates at 150 rpm. Find the angular speed in rad/s and the linear speed of a point on the rim.
examples.solution: Angular speed: ω = 150 rev/min × 2π rad/rev × 1 min/60 s = 300π/60 = 5π rad/s ≈ 15.71 rad/s. Linear speed: v = rω = 2(5π) = 10π ≈ 31.42 ft/s.

scaffold.title: The Unit Circle & Trigonometric Values
scaffold.content: The unit circle (radius 1, centered at origin) provides the foundation for all trig values. For any angle θ, the terminal point on the unit circle is (cos θ, sin θ). All six trig functions derive from this.
keyPoints: On unit circle: cos θ = x-coordinate, sin θ = y-coordinate
tan θ = sin θ/cos θ = y/x (undefined when x = 0)
csc θ = 1/sin θ, sec θ = 1/cos θ, cot θ = cos θ/sin θ
Reference angles: acute angle formed with x-axis; same trig values, sign determined by quadrant
ASTC (All Students Take Calculus): Q1 all+, Q2 sin/csc+, Q3 tan/cot+, Q4 cos/sec+

scaffold.title: Unit Circle Trig Values — Worked Examples

examples.problem: Evaluate all six trig functions at θ = 5π/6.
Evaluate all six trig functions at θ = 7π/4.
Find all angles θ in [0, 2π) where tan θ = √3.
examples.solution: tan θ = √3 when reference angle = π/3 (since tan(π/3) = √3). Tangent is positive in Q1 and Q3. θ = π/3 or θ = π + π/3 = 4π/3. Solutions: {π/3, 4π/3}.

problems.problem: A sprinkler rotates through 3π/4 radians. If the water reaches 20 feet, find: (a) the arc length of the watered area boundary, (b) the total area watered.
Evaluate without a calculator: (a) sin(4π/3), (b) cos(-3π/4), (c) tan(11π/6), (d) sec(2π/3).
Find all angles θ in [0, 2π) satisfying: (a) cos θ = -1/2, (b) sin θ = -√2/2.
hints: (a) cos = -1/2: ref angle π/3, cos negative in Q2 and Q3
(b) sin = -√2/2: ref angle π/4, sin negative in Q3 and Q4

scaffold.title: Graphing Trigonometric Functions
scaffold.content: The general sinusoidal form y = A·sin(B(x - C)) + D (or cosine) encodes amplitude, period, phase shift, and vertical shift. Tangent, cotangent, secant, and cosecant have different shapes but follow similar parameter rules.
keyPoints: |A| = amplitude (vertical stretch). A < 0: reflect over x-axis
Period: 2π/|B| for sin/cos; π/|B| for tan/cot
Phase shift: C units right (horizontal shift)
Vertical shift: D (new midline at y = D)
Sine: starts at midline, goes up. Cosine: starts at max
Tangent: period π, VA at x = π/2 + nπ, passes through origin
Secant/cosecant: reciprocal graphs of cos/sin, U-shaped branches between asymptotes

examples.problem: For y = 3·sin(2(x - π/4)) + 1, find amplitude, period, phase shift, vertical shift, midline, max, min, and describe the graph.
examples.solution: Amplitude: |3| = 3. Period: 2π/2 = π. Phase shift: π/4 right. Vertical shift: up 1, midline y = 1. Maximum: 1 + 3 = 4. Minimum: 1 - 3 = -2. Starting point: at x = π/4 (phase shift), y = 1 (midline), going up.

examples.problem: Write the equation of a cosine function with amplitude 4, period 6π, phase shift π/2 left, and midline y = -3.
examples.solution: Amplitude: A = 4. Period = 6π = 2π/B → B = 2π/(6π) = 1/3. Phase shift π/2 left → C = -π/2. Midline y = -3 → D = -3. Equation: y = 4·cos((1/3)(x + π/2)) - 3.

examples.problem: For y = -2·tan(x/2 - π/4) + 1, find period, phase shift, vertical asymptotes, and describe the graph.
examples.solution: Rewrite: y = -2·tan((1/2)(x - π/2)) + 1. Period: π/(1/2) = 2π. Phase shift: π/2 right. Vertical shift: up 1. Reflection (negative). VAs: (1/2)(x - π/2) = π/2 + nπ → x - π/2 = π + 2nπ → x = 3π/2 + 2nπ. Two consecutive VAs: x = -π/2 and x = 3π/2. Center between VAs: x = π/2, y = 1 (midpoint on graph due to shift).

problems.problem: For y = -2·cos(3x - π) + 4, rewrite in standard form and find all key features.
hints: Phase shift: π/3 right, midline: y = 4
problems.answer: y = -2·cos(3(x - π/3)) + 4. Amplitude: 2. Period: 2π/3. Phase shift: π/3 right. Midline: y = 4. Max: 6. Min: 2. Since A < 0, starts at minimum (y = 2) at x = π/3.

problems.problem: A temperature model is T(t) = 15·sin(π/12·(t - 8)) + 65, where t is hours past midnight. Find: (a) max/min temperatures and when they occur, (b) the period, (c) T(14).
hints: Max: 65+15=80 at sin=1, min: 65-15=50 at sin=-1

problems.problem: Write the equation of a sinusoidal function that passes through (0, 3), has maximum value 7, minimum value -1, and period π.
hints: At x=0, y=3 (midline) going up → use sine
problems.answer: Midline: D = 3. Amplitude: A = 4. B = 2. Since (0, 3) is on the midline and we want it going up: y = 4·sin(2x) + 3.

scaffold.title: Fundamental Trigonometric Identities
scaffold.content: Trig identities are equations true for all values in the domain. They are essential tools for simplifying expressions, verifying equations, and solving trig equations.
keyPoints: Pythagorean: sin²θ + cos²θ = 1, 1 + tan²θ = sec²θ, 1 + cot²θ = csc²θ
Reciprocal: csc θ = 1/sin θ, sec θ = 1/cos θ, cot θ = 1/tan θ
Quotient: tan θ = sin θ/cos θ, cot θ = cos θ/sin θ
Even-odd: cos(-θ) = cos θ, sin(-θ) = -sin θ, tan(-θ) = -tan θ
Cofunction: sin(π/2 - θ) = cos θ, tan(π/2 - θ) = cot θ, sec(π/2 - θ) = csc θ
Verifying identities: work one side only, transform to match the other. Common strategies: convert to sin/cos, factor, find common denominator, multiply by conjugate

examples.solution: Numerator: 1 - cos²θ = sin²θ (Pythagorean). So sin²θ/(sin θ · cos θ) = sin θ/cos θ = tan θ.

examples.problem: Verify: sec θ - cos θ = sin θ · tan θ.
examples.solution: LHS: sec θ - cos θ = 1/cos θ - cos θ = (1 - cos²θ)/cos θ = sin²θ/cos θ = sin θ · (sin θ/cos θ) = sin θ · tan θ = RHS. ✓

examples.problem: Verify: (1 + sin θ)/(cos θ) = (cos θ)/(1 - sin θ).
examples.solution: Cross-multiply to check: (1 + sin θ)(1 - sin θ) = cos θ · cos θ → 1 - sin²θ = cos²θ. This is the Pythagorean identity. ✓. Alternatively, work LHS: multiply by (1 - sin θ)/(1 - sin θ): (1 + sin θ)(1 - sin θ)/(cos θ(1 - sin θ)) = (1 - sin²θ)/(cos θ(1 - sin θ)) = cos²θ/(cos θ(1 - sin θ)) = cos θ/(1 - sin θ) = RHS. ✓
cot²θ · sin²θ = (cos²θ/sin²θ) · sin²θ = cos²θ. tan²θ · cos²θ = (sin²θ/cos²θ) · cos²θ = sin²θ. Sum: cos²θ + sin²θ = 1.

problems.problem: Verify: csc θ - sin θ = cos θ · cot θ.
hints: LHS: 1/sin θ - sin θ = (1 - sin²θ)/sin θ
= cos θ · (cos θ/sin θ) = cos θ · cot θ
problems.answer: LHS: csc θ - sin θ = (1 - sin²θ)/sin θ = cos²θ/sin θ = cos θ · (cos θ/sin θ) = cos θ · cot θ = RHS. ✓

scaffold.title: Solving Trigonometric Equations
scaffold.content: Solving trig equations involves isolating the trig function, finding reference angles, determining which quadrants give solutions, and accounting for periodicity for general solutions.
keyPoints: Isolate the trig function first (factor, use identities, substitute)
Find reference angle from the equation
Use ASTC to determine solution quadrants
On [0, 2π): list all specific solutions
General solution: add + 2nπ (for sin/cos) or + nπ (for tan) where n is any integer
Quadratic trig equations: factor or use quadratic formula with u-substitution
Always check for extraneous solutions when squaring was used

examples.problem: Solve 2·sin(x) - 1 = 0 on [0, 2π). Then give the general solution.
examples.solution: sin(x) = 1/2. Reference angle: π/6. Sin is positive in Q1 and Q2. x = π/6 or x = π - π/6 = 5π/6. On [0, 2π): {π/6, 5π/6}. General: x = π/6 + 2nπ or x = 5π/6 + 2nπ.
Let u = cos(x): 2u² - u - 1 = 0 → (2u + 1)(u - 1) = 0. u = -1/2 or u = 1. cos(x) = -1/2: ref angle π/3, cos negative in Q2, Q3. x = 2π/3 or x = 4π/3. cos(x) = 1: x = 0. Solutions: {0, 2π/3, 4π/3}.

tan²(x) = 3 → tan(x) = ±√3. tan(x) = √3: ref angle π/3, tan positive in Q1, Q3 → x = π/3, 4π/3. tan(x) = -√3: ref angle π/3, tan negative in Q2, Q4 → x = 2π/3, 5π/3. Solutions: {π/3, 2π/3, 4π/3, 5π/3}.

Let u = sin(x): 2u² + 3u + 1 = 0 → (2u + 1)(u + 1) = 0. u = -1/2 or u = -1. sin(x) = -1/2: ref angle π/6, sin negative in Q3, Q4 → x = 7π/6, 11π/6. sin(x) = -1: x = 3π/2. Solutions: {7π/6, 3π/2, 11π/6}.

hints: Cosine negative in Q2 and Q3
problems.answer: cos(x) = -√3/2. Ref angle: π/6. Q2: x = π - π/6 = 5π/6. Q3: x = π + π/6 = 7π/6. Solutions: {5π/6, 7π/6}.

hints: u = π/3 or u = 2π/3 (plus period additions)

problems.answer: sin(x)(2sin(x) - 1) = 0. sin(x) = 0: x = 0, π. sin(x) = 1/2: x = π/6, 5π/6. Solutions: {0, π/6, 5π/6, π}.

problems.problem: A pendulum swings through an angle of 5π/12 radians. If the pendulum is 80 cm long, find the arc length of the swing.
Evaluate without a calculator: sin(7π/6) + cos(5π/3) - tan(3π/4).
For y = -4·cos(π/3·(x + 1)) + 2, find amplitude, period, phase shift, midline, max, and min.
problems.answer: Amplitude: 4. Period: 2π/(π/3) = 6. Phase shift: 1 unit left. Midline: y = 2. Max: 2 + 4 = 6. Min: 2 - 4 = -2. Since A < 0, graph starts at minimum at x = -1.

problems.problem: Verify: (sin θ + cos θ)² = 1 + 2·sin θ·cos θ.
problems.answer: LHS: sin²θ + 2·sin θ·cos θ + cos²θ = (sin²θ + cos²θ) + 2·sin θ·cos θ = 1 + 2·sin θ·cos θ = RHS. ✓

problems.problem: The height (in meters) of a Ferris wheel seat is modeled by h(t) = -18·cos(πt/5) + 20, where t is in minutes. (a) Find the diameter and the height of the center. (b) Find h(2.5). (c) How long for one revolution? (d) At what times in the first revolution is the seat at 30 m?
problems.answer: (a) Amplitude = 18 → radius = 18 m → diameter = 36 m. Center height = midline = 20 m. Min height = 20 - 18 = 2 m (platform height). (b) h(2.5) = -18cos(π(2.5)/5) + 20 = -18cos(π/2) + 20 = -18(0) + 20 = 20 m. (c) Period = 2π/(π/5) = 10 minutes. (d) 30 = -18cos(πt/5) + 20 → cos(πt/5) = -10/18 = -5/9. πt/5 = arccos(-5/9) ≈ 2.0137. t = 5(2.0137)/π ≈ 3.204 min. Also πt/5 = 2π - 2.0137 ≈ 4.2695. t ≈ 5(4.2695)/π ≈ 6.796 min. Seat is at 30 m at t ≈ 3.20 min and t ≈ 6.80 min.
